Through statements from ISP officials, which were a mix of denials and contradictions (linked in telco_ack_quote), the government used an excuse of a subsea cable cut to deny the shutdown. However, independent reports and anonymous sources confirmed that the internet was deliberately cutoff through orders by the Kenyan government to disconnect circuits at sea cable landing stations.

event: After the military council announced they would seize Starlink devices, local businesses hosting access points in Mohnyin, Kachin State complied around Nov. 18, shutting down this avenue for internet access for locals. After a protracted shutdown of traditional internet and phone service which had been mostly ongoing for months since July across Kachin State, many cities started providing Starlink so people could have access to the internet. By announcing the seizure of Starlink devices with knowledge that people used them to access information and communicate using the internet, and given the context of past deliberate shutdowns of traditional internet providers in the area, the junta intentionally disrupted the internet. Rather than directing ISPs to follow a shutdown order, the junta instead threatened other local businesses who were acting as de facto ISPs to stop providing the service. (There had been reports of arrests of people providing Starlink in the country in 2024).
